p:
Since the discovery of solid molecular hydrogen in 1899, the nature of this phase has remained controversial
1 . It is now believed that the solid “Phase I” comprises rotating hydrogen molecules on a hexagonal close-packed lattice
2 . With increasing pressure the rotation becomes hindered
3 by intermolecular interactions, both steric and electrostatic, leading ultimately to phase transformations to a low temperature Phase II
4 , in which quadrupole–quadrupole interactions (EQQ) arrest the rotation
5 , and a high-pressure Phase III
6, 7 , in which steric interactions dominate.
